item.title: Petrol driver shortage: Ministers discuss supply issues
item.description: Ministers focused on the impact of the lorry driver shortage, with fuel the latest sector to be affected.

item.title: China declares all crypto-currency transactions illegal
item.description: Trading Bitcoin and other crypto-currenices is a criminal activity, China's central bank says.

item.title: Airport arrivals hit by passport gate failure
item.description: Passengers arriving at UK airports suffer delays after an IT problem hits self-service passport gates.

item.title: Thousands of energy customers facing bill shocks
item.description: People are awaiting decisions by the regulator about which surviving company will take on their supply.

item.title: Gas price crisis: Shift focus to using less energy, says boss
item.description: The government should concentrate on how people can use less energy to lower their bills, says boss.

item.title: Evergrande: Investors in the dark over $83m bond payment
item.description: Financial markets have been rocked this week by concerns over the firm's more than $300bn of debt.

item.title: Huawei's Meng Wanzhou to be freed in US deal
item.description: The row over Meng Wanzhou's detention in 2018 strained China's relations with Canada and the US.

item.title: Hospitality staff set to keep all their tips under rule change
item.description: The government is set to make it illegal for hospitality bosses to withhold tips from their workers.

item.title: Ministers weigh up visa changes to fix staff shortage
item.description: The government said it is "looking at options" to deal with labour shortages ahead of Christmas.

item.title: Climate change: Construction companies told to stop knocking down buildings
item.description: Britainâ€™s top engineers are urging the government to stop buildings being demolished.

item.title: Mondelez threatens trademark battle over bar's lilac packaging
item.description: Mondelez believes Primal Pantry's vegan fruit bar "exploits" the trademark of its Milka chocolates.

item.title: Ministers prepare for worst in gas price crisis
item.description: Business minister Paul Scully says the government needs to plan for a lengthy spell of high gas prices.

item.title: BP closes some sites due to lorry driver shortage
item.description: The oil firm said only "a handful" of sites are affected by the fuel supply issues.

item.title: Theranos trial: Elizabeth Holmes took US general's blood
item.description: James Mattis, a former defence secretary, said the Theranos founder convinced him her blood tests worked.

item.title: Inflation: Bank of England says price rises to top 4% by year-end
item.description: The Bank keeps interest rates at 0.1% and says there are signs of slowing economic growth.

item.title: Working from home: Staff abuse it, says City boss
item.description: Staff should not have the right to ask for flexible working from day one of new job, an employer says.

item.title: Advertising regulator to clampdown on greenwashing ads
item.description: The Advertising Standards Authority will launch inquiries into false environmental claims made in ads.

item.title: Millions face winter finance squeeze, says charity
item.description: Low-income families face a Â£710 rise in costs, the Joseph Rowntree Foundation estimates.

item.title: EU rules to force USB-C chargers for all phones
item.description: Manufacturers could be forced to change devices to a uniform charging system.

item.title: Evergrande: Shares in crisis-hit firm jump as debt deadline looms
item.description: The debt-laden developer is due to make a $83.5m interest payment on an overseas bond on Thursday.

item.title: Food firms warn of panic-buying this Christmas
item.description: Gaps on supermarket shelves may become commonplace as labour shortages bite, industry bodies say.

item.title: The edible insects coming to a supermarket near you
item.description: A number of firms are now farming locusts and mealworms for human consumption.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'In my business, you eat what you kill'
item.description: Music executive Riki Bleau shares his business advice for our CEO Secrets series.

item.title: German elections: Businesses face future without Merkel
item.description: Many companies in Germany are focused on short-term survival in the hope of medium-term revival.

item.title: How 'nerd' culture powered through the pandemic
item.description: Meet the online content creators beating the odds to build successful careers from their passions.

item.title: Can apps manage our chronic health conditions?
item.description: A Swedish tech firm has created an app to help alleviate people's joint pain.

item.title: 'Looking back, it was an amazing thing I did'
item.description: Meet the founder on a 10-year mission to disrupt Japan's rigid work culture.

item.title: Gen Z battles to bring back unions, one Starbucks at a time
item.description: Younger Americans are reviving US labour activism amid stagnant wages and Covid hardship.

item.title: Why taking up an instrument has struck a chord for so many
item.description: The pandemic led to around 1m UK adults learning an instrument and many taking music lessons.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'You can run a business and have a baby'
item.description: Planning for a maternity leave when you're the boss of a fast-growing company.

item.title: Why even giant ships can't solve the shipping crisis
item.description: A shortage of vessels is hampering global trade and may lead to empty shelves before Christmas.

item.title: Amazon's Cape Town base: The battle to save South African culture
item.description: Some indigenous groups say the planned office in Cape Town is on culturally important land.
